channel.title: SCOTUSblog Podcast
channel.itunes:subtitle: Tom Goldstein podcasts on various legal topics related to the Supreme Court of the United States
channel.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
channel.itunes:summary: Podcasts originally published on SCOTUSblog, a blog written by lawyers, students, and journalists devoted to coverage of the Supreme Court of the United States
channel.itunes:keywords: justices, scalia, roberts, legal, law, judicial, ginsburg, sotomayor, oral argument, alito

item.title: Shaping America podcast with Ed Mannino
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: SCOTUSblog interviews Ed Mannino, author of Shaping America: The Supreme Court and American Society.
item.itunes:summary: SCOTUSblog interviews trial lawyer and legal historian Ed Mannino about his book, Shaping America: The Supreme Court and American Society, a comprehensive history of the Supreme Court.

item.title: Snyder v. Phelps: Arguments for Petitioner
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Stephen R. McAllister, Solicitor General of Kansas, representing amici Kansas, forty-seven other states, and the District of Columbia.
item.itunes:summary: Stephen R. McAllister presents the arguments for the petitioner. Mr. McAllister is the Solicitor General of Kansas and represents amici Kansas, forty-seven other states, and the District of Columbia in support of the petitioner.

item.title: Snyder v. Phelps: Arguments for Respondent
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Margie Phelps, arguing counsel for Respondent.
item.itunes:summary: Margie J. Phelps presents the arguments for respondent. Ms. Phelps is also arguing counsel for respondent.

item.title: Schwarzenegger v. Entertainment Merchants : Arguments for Petitioner
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: S. Kyle Duncan, Appellate Chief, Louisiana Department of Justice presents the arguments for petitioner
item.itunes:summary: S. Kyle Duncan, Appellate Chief, Louisiana Department of Justice presents the arguments for petitioner. Mr. Duncan represents amici Lousiana et al. in support of petitioner

item.title: Schwarzenegger v. Entertainment Merchants : Arguments for Respondent
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Paul M. Smith, Jenner & Block, presents arguments for respondent
item.itunes:summary: Paul M. Smith, Jenner & Block, presents arguments for respondent. Mr. Smith is also arguing counsel for respondent

item.title: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn: Arguments for Petitioners
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: David A. Cortman, Alliance Defense Fund, presents arguments for petitioners
item.itunes:summary: David A. Cortman, Alliance Defense Fund, presents arguments for petitioner. Mr. Cortman is lead counsel for petitioner Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization

item.title: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn: Arguments for Respondents
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Francisco M. Negrón, Associate Executive Director & General Counsel, National School Boards Association, presents arguments for respondents
item.itunes:summary: Francisco M. Negrón, Associate Executive Director & General Counsel, National School Boards Association, presents arguments for respondents. The National School Boards Association filed an amicus brief in the case.

item.title: Schwarzenegger v. Plata: Arguments for appellees
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Paul D. Clement, King & Spalding LLP
item.itunes:summary: Paul D. Clement, King & Spalding LLP, presents arguments for appellees. Mr. Clement is counsel to appellee Ralph Coleman.

item.title: Schwarzenegger v. Plata: Arguments for appellants
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Carter G. Phillips, Sidley Austin LLP, presents arguments for appellants.
item.itunes:summary: Carter G. Phillips, Sidley Austin LLP, presents arguments for appellants. Mr. Phillips is counsel to appellant Arnold Schwarzenegger

item.title: Thompson v. North American Stainless: Arguments for petitioner
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Helen Norton, University of Colorado Law School, presents arguments for petitioner.
item.itunes:summary: Helen Norton, University of Colorado Law School, counsel to amici National Women’s Law Center et al., presents arguments for petitioner. Professor Norton is counsel to amici National Women’s Law Center et al.

item.title: Thompson v. North American Stainless: Arguments for respondent
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Leigh Latherow, VanAntwerp, Monge, Jones, Edwards & McCann, LLP, presents arguments for respondent.
item.itunes:summary: Leigh Latherow, VanAntwerp, Monge, Jones, Edwards & McCann, LLP presents arguments for respondent. Ms. Latherow is counsel to respondent North American Stainless, LP.,

item.title: Skinner v. Switzer: Arguments for Respondent
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Edward C. Dawson, Partner at Yetter Coleman LLP, representing respondent.
item.itunes:summary: Edward C. Dawson presents the arguments for the respondent. Mr. Dawson is a Partner at Yetter Coleman LLP. Note: We had also planned (and hoped) to have counsel for petitioner Henry Skinner participate in the podcast, but at the last minute he was unable to do so. Thus, unlike earlier podcasts, this podcast features only counsel for the respondent, which we are posting without regard to her likelihood of success in the case.

item.title: Chamber of Commerce v. Whiting: Arguments for Respondent
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Mary R. O’Grady, Solicitor General of Arizona, representing respondent.
item.itunes:summary: Mary R. O'Grady presents the arguments for the respondent. Ms. O'Grady is the Solicitor General of Arizona.

item.title: Podcast interview – Erwin Chemerinsky’s The Conservative Assault on the Constitution
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: A discussion with Dean Erwin Chemerinsky about his book, The Conservative Assault on the Constitution.
item.itunes:summary: SCOTUSblog interviews founding Dean of UC Irvine Law School and constitutional scholar Erwin Chemerinsky about his book The Conservative Assault on the Constitution.

item.title: Chamber of Commerce v. Whiting: Arguments for Petitioners
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Carter G. Phillips, Sidley Austin LLP, representing petitioners.
item.itunes:summary: Carter G. Phillips presents the arguments for the petitioners. Mr. Phillips is a partner at Sidley Austin LLP.

item.title: Doe v. Reed: Arguments for Respondent
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Robert McKenna gives the arguments on the petitioner's side
item.itunes:summary: Washington Attorney General Robert McKenna, who argued before the Supreme Court, gives the arguments on the state's side.

item.title: Doe v. Reed: Arguments for Petitioner
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: James Bopp gives the arguments on the petitioner's side
item.itunes:summary: James Bopp, who argued before the Supreme Court, gives the arguments on the petition signers' side.

item.title: City of Ontario v. Quon: Arguments for Respondent
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Dieter Dammeier gives the arguments on the respondent's side
item.itunes:summary: Dieter Dammeier, who argued before the Supreme Court, gives the arguments on the respondent's side.

item.title: City of Ontario v. Quon: Arguments for Petitioner
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Kent Richland gives the arguments on the petitioner's side
item.itunes:summary: Kent Richland, who argued before the Supreme Court, gives the arguments on the city's side.

item.title: Christian Legal Society v. Martinez: Arguments for Respondents
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Paul Smith gives the arguments on the respondents' side
item.itunes:summary: Paul Smith, representing the amicus party Hastings Outlaw, gives the arguments on the respondents' side.

item.title: Christian Legal Society v. Martinez: Arguments for Petitioner
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Michael McConnell gives the arguments on the petitioner's side
item.itunes:summary: Judge Michael McConnell, who argued before the Supreme Court, gives the arguments on the petitioner's side.

item.title: Magwood v. Patterson: Arguments for Petitioner
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Prof. John Blume gives the arguments on the petitioner's side
item.itunes:summary: Prof. John Blume, representing the amicus party the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, gives the arguments on the criminal defendant's side.

item.title: Magwood v. Patterson: Arguments for Respondent
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Alabama Solicitor General Corey Maze gives the arguments on the respondent's side
item.itunes:summary: Alabama Solicitor General Corey Maze gives the arguments on the state government's side.

item.title: McDonald v. Chicago: Argument Against Gun Violence
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: The arguments of the Brady Center to Prevent Gun Violence for considering a public interest in gun regulations
item.itunes:summary: Jon Lowy of amicus the Brady Center to Prevent Gun Violence gives arguments for considering a public interest in gun regulations, should the Second Amendment be incorporated.

item.title: McDonald v. Chicago: Argument for Incorporation Through Due Process
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Leonard Niehoff, counsel to the amicus Anti-Defamation League, gives the arguments in favor of incorporation through the Due Process Clause.
item.itunes:summary: Leonard Niehoff, counsel to the amicus Anti-Defamation League, gives the arguments in favor of incorporation (if any) through the Due Process Clause.

item.title: McDonald v. Chicago: Argument for Incorporation Through Privileges or Immunities
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Ilya Shapiro of the Cato Institute gives the arguments in favor of incorporation through the Privileges or Immunities Clause.
item.itunes:summary: Ilya Shapiro of the Cato Institute gives the arguments in favor of incorporating the Second Amendment through the Privileges or Immunities Clause.

item.title: McDonald v. Chicago: Argument Against Incorporation
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Charles Dyke, counsel for an amicus supporting the respondent, gives arguments against incorporating the Second Amendment.
item.itunes:summary: Charles Dyke, counsel for the amicus Board of Education of Chicago et al., argues against incorporating the Second Amendment.

item.title: McDonald v. Chicago: Arguments for the Petitioners
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Alan Gura, counsel to McDonald, gives the arguments in favor of incorporation.
item.itunes:summary: Alan Gura, counsel to Otis McDonald, gives the arguments in favor of incorporation of the Second Amendment.

item.title: Interview with David Stras, Former Clarence Thomas Clerk
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: SCOTUSblog interviews Prof. David Stras on his experience clerking for Justice Thomas
item.itunes:summary: SCOTUSblog interviews Prof. David Stras on his experience clerking for Justice Thomas.

item.title: Holder v. Humanitarian Law Project: Arguments for the Petitioners
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Prof. Peter Margulies gives the arguments for the Attorney General's side
item.itunes:summary: Prof. Peter Margulies, representing the amicus party “Scholars, Attorneys, and Former Public Officials with Experience in Terrorism-Related Issues," gives the arguments for the government.

item.title: Jack Greenberg on Brown v. Board of Education
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Jack Greenberg discusses the experience of arguing Brown v. Board of Education
item.itunes:summary: Jack Greenberg discusses the experience of arguing Brown v. Board of Education, and the meaning of the decision.

item.title: Nina Totenberg on Brown v. Board of Education
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Nina Totenberg introduces her three-part series of recordings on the case for NPR
item.itunes:summary: Nina Totenberg introduces her three-part series of recordings on the case for NPR.

item.title: Erwin Chemerinsky on the Supreme Court and Re-Segregation
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Erwin Chemerinsky on the Supreme Court and the re-segregation of American public schools
item.itunes:summary: University of California, Irvine law school dean Erwin Chemerinsky discusses segregation today in American public schools and the Court's rulings on desegregation and integration programs.

item.title: David Cecelski: The Unexpected Consequences of Brown v. Board of Education
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: SCOTUSblog interviews historian David Cecelski about the consequences of the Brown v. Board of Education decision.
item.itunes:summary: SCOTUSblog interviews historian David Cecelski about the consequences of the Brown v. Board of Education decision.

item.itunes:subtitle: Tom Goldstein interviews Vernon Jordan about the impact of the Court on the black community
item.itunes:summary: Tom Goldstein interviews Vernon Jordan about the impact of the Court on the black community.

item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Arguments for the petitioner in Berghuis v. Smith
item.itunes:summary: Arguments for the petitioner in the Supreme Court case Berghuis v. Smith. The speaker is Kent Scheidegger, representing the Criminal Justice Legal Foundation as amicus curiae.

item.title: Berghuis v. Smith: Counsel for Respondent Smith
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Arguments for the respondent in Berghuis v. Smith
item.itunes:summary: Arguments for the respondent in the Supreme Court case Berghuis v. Smith. The speaker is James Sterling Lawrence, counsel to Diapolis Smith.

item.title: American Needle v. NFL: Counsel for American Needle
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Arguments for the petitioner in American Needle v. NFL
item.itunes:summary: Arguments for the petitioner in the Supreme Court case American Needle v. NFL. The speaker is Meir Feder of Jones Day, counsel to American Needle.

item.title: American Needle v. NFL: Counsel Supporting the NFL
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Arguments for the respondent in American Needle v. NFL
item.itunes:summary: Arguments for the respondent in American Needle v. NFL. The speaker is Shepard Goldfein of Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom, representing the National hockey League as amicus curiae.

item.title: Free Enterprise Fund v. PCAOB: Counsel for the Free Enterprise Fund
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Arguments for the petitioner in Free Enterprise Fund v. Public Company Accounting Oversight Board
item.itunes:summary: Arguments for the petitioner in the Supreme Court case Free Enterprise Fund v. Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. The speaker is Christian Vergonis of Jones Day, counsel for the Free Enterprise Fund.

item.title: Free Enterprise Fund v. PCAOB: Counsel Supporting the PCAOB
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Arguments for the respondent in Free Enterprise Fund v. Public Company Accounting Oversight Board
item.itunes:summary: Arguments for the respondent in the Supreme Court case Free Enterprise Fund v. Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. The speaker is NYU law professor Richard Pildes, representing former chairmen of the Securities and Exchange Commission as amici curiae.

item.title: Biskupic Interview
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Book interview with Joan Biskupic
item.itunes:summary: Tom Goldstein interviews Joan Biskupic about her 2009 biography of Justice Antonin Scalia.

item.title: More on Cert. Petitions with no Split
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: More on Cert. Petitions with no Split
item.itunes:summary: In this episode, Kevin Russell elaborates on a previous post of his regarding how to present a case to the Court when there is not circuit split.
item.itunes:keywords: Kevin Russell, Tom Goldstein, SCOTUSblog, Supreme Court, cert, circuit split, practice pointer, SCOTUS, law, legal, lawyer

item.title: Applications for Stay
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Applications for stay at the Court, with guest Troy Cahill.
item.itunes:summary: After a hiatus, the SCOTUSblog podcast is back. Today, Troy Cahill, who woked as a staff attorney in the clerk's office of the Supreme Court prior to joining Akin, discusses the ins and outs of applications for stay.
item.itunes:keywords: Supreme Court, SCOTUS, SCOTUSblog, applications for stay, O'Connor, Cahill, Goldstein, Howe, Russell, Tom Goldstein

item.title: Professor Charles Fried
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: A conversation with Professor Charles Fried about his new book, Modern Liberty and the Limits of Government.
item.itunes:summary: In today's episode, Tom talks with Professor Fried about his new book, Modern Liberty and the Limits of Government.
item.itunes:keywords: Fried, Harvard, Supreme Court, Law, SCOTUS, SCOTUSblog, legal, Goldstein, Tom Goldstein

item.title: More Thoughts on the Docket
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Tom Goldstein expresses further thoughts on the Court's docket.
item.itunes:summary: In today's episode, Tom elaborates on his earlier post about the state of the Court's docket, the cert. process as a whole, and the role of law clerks in screening cases.
item.itunes:keywords: Supreme Court, docket, SCOTUS, SCOTUSblog, law, legal, judges, justice

item.title: Election Law with Rick Hasen
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Election Law at the Supreme Court with Rick Hasen.
item.itunes:summary: In today's episode, we discuss Election Law at the Supreme Court with Professor Rick Hasen of the Election Law Blog and Loyala Law School in L.A.
item.itunes:keywords: Election, election law, Rick Hasen, SCOTUSblog, Supreme Court, legal, law, campaign finance

item.title: Patent Law at the Supreme Court
item.itunes:author: Ken Bass
item.itunes:subtitle: Ken Bass discusses patent law at the Supreme Court.
item.itunes:summary: The SCOTUSblog Podcast returns, and our episode today features a discussion of patent law at the Supreme Court with our guest Ken Bass of the firm Sterne, Kessler, Goldstein, and Fox.
item.itunes:keywords: Supreme Court, patents, patent law, IP, intellectual property, law, legal, SCOTUS, SCOTUSblog, KSR, Microsoft, Ken Bass, SKGF

item.title: Practice Pointers #3: The BIO
item.itunes:author: Kevin Russell
item.itunes:subtitle: Today, Kevin Russell discusses how to effectively oppose certiorari.
item.itunes:summary: In today's episode of the podcast, we return to our practice pointers series as Kevin Russell discusses how to effectively oppose cert.
item.itunes:keywords: Kevin Russell, Tom Goldstein, Supreme Court, cert, brief in opposition, SCOTUSblog, law, legal

item.title: Interview with Linda Greenhouse
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Tom interviews Linda Greenhouse of the New York Times.
item.itunes:summary: In today's episode, Tom talks with award-winning New York Times reporter Linda Greenhouse about her book, the two new Justices, and the controversy regarding her remarks at Radcliffe College.
item.itunes:keywords: New York Times, Linda Greenhouse, Tom Goldstein, SCOTUS, SCOTUSblog, Supreme Court

item.title: Interview with Nina Totenberg
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Tom's interview with Nina Totenberg.
item.itunes:summary: On this edition of the SCOTUSblog podcast, Tom interviews Nina Totenberg about the Supreme Court press corps, what happens when the Court hands down a big decision, and what Justice Ginsburg may be feeling now that she is the only woman on the Court.
item.itunes:keywords: NPR, Tom Goldstein, Nina Totenberg, Supreme Court, SCOTUS, SCOTUSblog, Legal Affairs, Interview

item.title: Practice Pointers #2: What NOT To Do
item.itunes:author: Amy Howe
item.itunes:subtitle: How to avoid common mistakes when drafting a cert. petition.
item.itunes:summary: In this episode of the SCOTUSblog podcast, Amy Howe of Howe & Russell talks about how to avoid common mistakes when drafting a cert. petition.
item.itunes:keywords: Cert., Supreme Court, Law, Legal, Amy Howe, Tom Goldstein, Petition, Court

item.title: Practice Pointers on the Cert. Criteria
item.itunes:author: Tom Goldstein
item.itunes:subtitle: In the premiere episode of the SCOTUSblog podcast, Tom Goldstein details the criteria that the Supreme Court uses when considering a cert. grant.
item.itunes:summary: In the premiere episode of the SCOTUSblog podcast, Tom Goldstein details the criteria that the Supreme Court uses when considering a cert. grant.
item.itunes:keywords: Supreme Court, cert., certiorari, cert. petition, Tom Goldstein, SCOTUSblog, Howe, Russell
